--- title: Edit Distances keywords: fastai sidebar: home_sidebar summary: "Compare sequences using the number of edits needed to match them" description: "Compare sequences using the number of edits needed to match them" nb_path: "23_multi_edit_distances.ipynb" ---
{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

The distances between any two sequences can be represented as the number of changes needed to make them identical. Sequences s1 and s2 can be given as parameters to each of the distance measures below.

{% raw %}

optimal_distance[source]

optimal_distance(s1, s2, match=0, mismatch=-1, gap=-1)

Computes the optimal matching distance between two sequences using the Needleman-Wunsch algorithm based on Devon Ryan's implementation found here.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
from pysan.editdistances import optimal_distance
s1 = [1,1,1,2,2,3,2,4,4,3,2,1,2,3,3,3,2,2,1,1,1]
s2 = [1,1,2,2,3,2,4,4,3,2,1,2,3,2,2,2,3,3,2,4,4]
optimal_distance(s1,s2)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

levenshtein_distance[source]

levenshtein_distance(s1, s2)

Computes the Levenshtein II distance between two sequences, which is the optimal distance using only insertions and deletions. This is identical to the get_optimal_distance method with a mismatch cost of ~infinity (-9999999) and a gap cost of -1. See the get_optimal_distance method with its default parameters for the Levenshtein I distance.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
from pysan.editdistances import levenshtein_distance
s1 = [1,1,1,2,2,3,2,4,4,3,2,1,2,3,3,3,2,2,1,1,1]
s2 = [1,1,2,2,3,2,4,4,3,2,1,2,3,2,2,2,3,3,2,4,4]
levenshtein_distance(s1,s2)
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

hamming_distance[source]

hamming_distance(s1, s2)

Computes the Hamming distance between two sequences, which is the optimal distance using only substitutions (no indels). This is identical to the get_optimal_distance method with a mismatch cost of -1 and a gap cost of ~infinity (-999999). Note that this can only be used on sequences of the same length given the infinite cost of gaps.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
from pysan.editdistances import hamming_distance
s1 = [1,1,1,2,2,3,2,4,4,3,2,1,2,3,3,3,2,2,1,1,1]
s2 = [1,1,2,2,3,2,4,4,3,2,1,2,3,2,2,2,3,3,2,4,4]
hamming_distance(s1,s2)
{% endraw %}
